results.title: The Sopranos. Season 3 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Steve Buscemi, Daniel Attias, Jack Bender, John Patterson, Henry J. Bronchtein, Tim Van Patten, Allen Coulter, David Chase, Ilene Landress, Chase Films, Brad Grey Television and Home Box Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Sopranos”.
The third season of this award-winning television series finds the Soprano family going about their business unaware that the FBI have begun a covert surveillance of their every move. But as the series progresses, the ever watchful eye of the Feds becomes less important than the personal experiences of the New Jersey crime family. Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) is still in therapy and though he is still baiting psychoanalyst Dr. Melfi (Lorraine Bracco), he is getting closer to understanding the source of his anxiety attacks: they are triggered by memories of his violent childhood. But with the death of his mother, Livia (Nancy Marchand), Tony has to deal with the twin demons of rage and guilt. Tony also has to deal with his daughter Meadow’s awakening sexuality (including her falling in love with a black man) as well as with the spiritual angst of his wife, Carmella (Edie Falco), who is increasingly disturbed by the ethical implications of her being a partner to a mobster. It’s only when he meets the beautiful Gloria (Annabella Sciorra) that things start looking up for Tony, but soon, in true Soprano’s style, her emotional instability creates a dangerous domestic situation for him. Outstanding episodes in this series include “Employee of the month”, which deals with the rape of Dr. Melfi, the black comedy of “Pine barrens”, directed by Steve Buscemi, and the horrifying violence of “University” which features the abusive relationship between a mobster and one of the strippers at the Bada Bing. The dark exploration of masculinity, abuse and violence which is central to this episode exemplifies what is unique to The Sopranos: terrific writing, outstanding performances and a daring audacity to fully explore the brutality of contemporary culture. The mores and ethics of organised crime seem an apt metaphor for the contemporary world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Steve Buscemi, Daniel Attias, Jack Bender, John Patterson, Henry J. Bronchtein, Tim Van Patten, Allen Coulter, David Chase, Ilene Landress, Chase Films, Brad Grey Television and Home Box Office

results.title: The Sopranos. Season 2 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Henry J. Bronchtein, John Patterson, Tim Van Patten, Lee Tamahori, Martin Bruestle, Allen Coulter, Ilene Landress, Home Box Office, Chase Films and Brillstein-Grey Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Sopranos”.
In the second series of the outstanding television series about the day to day realities of a New Jersey Mafia family, we find that Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) is still prone to bouts of existential despair while at the same time having to be the boss-man of an organised crime family. While dealing with the running of his myriad operations Tony also has to keep the facts of his adulterous affairs from his suspicious wife, Carmella (Edie Falco) and make sure that his increasingly rebellious children don’t undermine him. It is one of the major achievements of the series that though the criminal and violent world it portrays is specific, unique and tinged with the romanticism of Golden Age Hollywood representations of crime and gangsters, it nevertheless manages to make Tony’s ethical and psychological choices resonate with the everyday realities of the viewer’s life. In Series Two, Tony returns to his psychiatrist and also returns to the family home in Naples. This episode, “Commendatori” is a series highlight, revolving around the glaring discrepancies between the Italo-American conceptions of the “old country” and the realities of contemporary Europe. Other outstanding episodes in series two include “D-Girl” where Christopher (Michael Imperioli) finds hidden talents as an actor and “Knight in white satin armour” where the tensions between Janie, Ritchie and Tony resolve in a violent and unexpected manner. But every episode in this adult cynical series is of excellent value.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Henry J. Bronchtein, John Patterson, Tim Van Patten, Lee Tamahori, Martin Bruestle, Allen Coulter, Ilene Landress, Home Box Office, Chase Films and Brillstein-Grey Entertainment

results.title: The Sopranos. Season 1 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Matthew Penn, Andy Wolk, Tim Van Patten, Lorraine Senna, Alan Taylor, Allen Coulter, John Patterson, Nick Gomez, Daniel Attias, David Chase, Ilene Landress, Chase Films, Brillstein-Grey Entertainment and Home Box Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Sopranos”.
The first season of the multi-Emmy Award winning series which brilliantly portrays the everyday lives of a New Jersey crime family. Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini), though ostensibly in the Waste Management business is really one of the heads of a large Mafia family. When the series begins he is disturbed by the on-set of a mid-life crisis in which the arrival of a nest of ducks in the family swimming pool precipitates dizzy-spells and increasingly disturbing dreams. He begins secret sessions with a psychiatrist, played by Lorraine Bracco, in which he slowly divulges the issues in his life. They include dealing with the suspicions of his intelligent Catholic wife, Carmella (Edie Falco); the traumas of seeing his daughter, Meadow (Jamie-Lynn Sigler), leave adolescence behind and prepare for College; and his concerns with his slacker son, Anthony Junior (Robert Iler). On top of this he has to deal with the constant undermining by his tough-bitch mother (Nancy Marchand) and the wheeling and dealing of his uncle, Junior (Dominic Chianese). Its only when he is with his “boys”, the “capos” that form his Mafia Crew - Paulie (Tony Sirico), Christopher (Michael Imperioli) and Silvio (Steven Van Zandt) - that Tony can relax. But even then, business always intrudes … With a consistently brilliant cast, tough and witty writing and a complex examination of materialism and contemporary American society, “The Sopranos” manages to create an ambiguous moral epic out of its study of power, corruption and money. Violent and uncompromising, the series delivers a narrative sweep that has the breadth of the classical nineteenth century novel but its language, vision and cynicism plants it firmly in the twenty-first. Created by David Chase and featuring direction by noted independent directors such as Nick Gomez, “The Sopranos” deserves the acclaim heaped upon it. In its moral complexity, insight and daring it leaves the products of the Hollywood motion picture industry for dead.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matthew Penn, Andy Wolk, Tim Van Patten, Lorraine Senna, Alan Taylor, Allen Coulter, John Patterson, Nick Gomez, Daniel Attias, David Chase, Ilene Landress, Chase Films, Brillstein-Grey Entertainment and Home Box Office

results.title: Outer planets
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Media Four Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Solar System”.
Uses special effects to create the impression of what is known of the outer planets - Jupitor, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, Pluto. Explains why life cannot be sustained on these planets. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Sun
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Media Four Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Solar System”.
Provides a theory of how the sun was created and indicates its value to earth in terms of energy. Also gives some insight into the nature of the sun’s surface and the relationship between sunspots and weather patterns.

results.title: The Earth
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance, Stanton Films and Media Four Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Solar System”.
Provides information about the planet Earth - how its distance from the sun is the optimum distance for sustaining life, the notions of rotation and gravitational pull, the earth’s structure and the movement of the Earth’s crust, i.e., tectonic plates.

results.title: The Moon
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Stanton Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Solar System”.
Provides information about the structural characteristics of the Moon and its effect on our planet. Shows that the moon is a satellite of the Earth, that its gravity is different to that of Earth, how it affects the Earth’s tides and why its surface is pitted with craters. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Inner planets
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Media Four Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Solar System”.
Uses special effects to create an impression of what is known of the structural character of the inner planets - Mercury, Venus and Mars. explains why life cannot be sustained on these planets. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Jane Seymour
results.creator_credit: John Glenister, Ronald Travers and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Six wives of Henry VIII”.
After his stormy and fatal relationship with Anne Boleyn, Henry VIII falls in love with her absolute antithesis - the shy and devout Jane Seymour. Calm, serene, gentle and giving, she comforts and cherishes her king with loyalty and love - she even bears him a son. But the lives of both Jane and her child soon come to a tragic end.
